Compiled on Ubuntu. Not able to test because using wrong syntax or missing something else:

```
bitcoin-cli fundrawtransaction "0200000001f7739b1278e8e0df75a1f692fbface31b09d4dc7b4ddb2f20dec698e7617cd310000000000ffffffff0150c30000000000001600147c5ac840b455af9f9b3da2c327275c0b0e985e7600000000" {} false '{"pubkeys" : "02b1f9f65bdf8e686333be0ac8979908ae8aeeee33e396c446ba2b17348

> Concept ACK
> 
> Compiled on Ubuntu. Not able to test because using wrong syntax or missing something else:
> 
> ```
> bitcoin-cli fundrawtransaction "0200000001f7739b1278e8e0df75a1f692fbface31b09d4dc7b4ddb2f20dec698e7617cd310000000000ffffffff0150c30000000000001600147c5ac840b455af9f9b3da2c327275c0b0e985e7600000000" {} false '{"pubkeys" : "02b1f9f65bdf8e686333be0ac8979908ae8aeeee33e396c

> `pubkeys` is an array, not a string. The correct command would be:
> 
> ```
> bitcoin-cli fundrawtransaction "0200000001f7739b1278e8e0df75a1f692fbface31b09d4dc7b4ddb2f20dec698e7617cd310000000000ffffffff0150c30000000000001600147c5ac840b455af9f9b3da2c327275c0b0e985e7600000000" {} false '{"pubkeys" : ["02b1f9f65bdf8e686333be0ac8979908ae8aeeee33e396c446ba2b17348a32335c"]}'
> ```

Reading the code, it feels like I didn't provide the right solv

"to ensure a sufficient feer is attained for the requested feerate" ?
nit: add a reference to `txNew.vin[nIn]` since it's used 3 times here
`txNew.vin[nIn]` is used three times here, just set a variable to reference it?
Not immediately obvious to me why this change is necessary. \n\nProbably requires more extensive comment?
In other words, how did selection of inputs work before this?

CTxOuts are needed for fee estimation and knowing the values of the outputs being selected. For inputs the wallet knows about, it would fetch the outputs from the wallet (obviously). Otherwise it would basically ignore them. So to support external inputs, either the user would have to enter the output info (bad UX IMO) or we can fetch it from the UTXO set.
Done
Done
Done
Done
This seems like an advanced feature, so maybe move to "options"?
Why not a reference instead of a pointer?\n\nIs there any reason not to move this to `SigningProvider` as a method?
I don't think this really belongs as part of options. It's not like a setting, just additional data needed.

I changed this to a reference.\n\nI don't think this really makes sense as part of SigningProvider. SigningProvider is to provide data for signing and is agnostic of what is being signed and how it is being signed. To add this to SigningProvider would violate that. Also, that would imply adding every other signing function to SigningProvider as well, and I don't think we should do that.
This is a bit more complicated than it needs to be, you can drop the second `coin_control &&`
unnecessary `.getID()`
Done
Done

This is causing intermittent failures for me. It's failing about 20%. Here's the traceback:
```
File "/bitcoin/test/functional/rpc_psbt.py", line 505, in run_test
    assert_raises_rpc_error(-4, "Missing solving data for estimating transaction size", self.nodes[1].walletcreatefundedpsbt, [{"txid": ext_utxo['txid'], "vout": ext_utxo['vout']}], {self.nodes[0].getnewaddress(): 10 + ext_utxo['am
I think I've fixed this.
I ran it 20 times and could not trigger any failures. Looks good.
Maybe we should require the user to provide the TXO too?
Why is `options` losing its explicit ref typing?

This `else` is for an `if(txid is in wallet)` ... but what we actually want to check is `if(outpoint is in wallet)`. If you try to spend an output you don't know from a wallet transaction (e.g. by sending coins to a peer then trying to spend their output), this logic will simply fail -- it will `return false;` a few lines above when trying to compute `wtx.GetSpendSize` on the outpoint.\n
I think you need to subtract the coin value from `value_to_select`. This looks like a rebasing error.

Would be good to add a functional test which funds a transaction using external inputs, asserting that the wallet balance would be insufficient without the external inputs. (As in https://github.com/ElementsProject/elements/pull/755/ which is a rough analogue of this PR.)
I don't think it should be required. It could be an option like for the `signrawtransaction*` RPCs.
Oops. should be fixed.
I think I've resolved this.
Should be fixed. Also added a test.

This line will prevent you from adding the "Missing solving data for estimating transaction size" test that @jonatack suggests, since `SelectCoins` fails and the user will instead see "Insufficient funds".\n\nOne hacky fix may be to just return true here without selecting any coins, trusting that `CreateTransaction` will fail shortly thereafter.
